--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Is it right to ignore symmetries?  Don't you have to
> train/test
> the net's ability to deal with them?

Well, the best first move is clear: the center.

If it is still open, the center is also the optimal
second move.

But consider the case where you play second, and your
opponent begins by playing in the center, so the board
looks like this:

0  0  0
0 -1  0
0  0  0

(Zero is an empty space, 1 is a friendly-occupied
space, and -1 is an enemy occupied space.).

Okay, so what is the optimal move here?

It's one of the corners, rather than one of the
non-corner edge spaces, but any corner play is
logically equivalent to any other corner play. 

So accounting for symmetry, with the center occupied
there are really only two possible moves to make: play
in a corner or play on a non-corner edge.

An evolved neural network that plays in the upper
right corner isn't going to be any better than one
that plays in the lower left corner at this point in
the game, right?

Derek
